body: most cases do comes with rtol i guess, and i think we are fine as long as they are not flaky
@tqchen #1791
Ideally it would be great to have some tools helping run a test for 1000 times before it is merged, so that the choice of thresholds won't bother further commits.

@junrushao1994 thank you. I was able to reproduce the error. On my machine, typical numeric error is `1e-7` or less, which is a bit higher than the default value of `atol` (1e-8). Most of the time, relative tolerance prevents assert from triggering but in rare cases RNG happens to generate operands close to zero. In such cases relative tolerance become infinitesimal, so the error condition hits. Increasing `atol` seems to be a correct fix. I am approving the PR.

As @junrushao1994 also points out, we use `assert_allclose` extensively. In the same time, `atol` are only set in rare cases, which is probably wrong as we may see now.

```
tvm $ git grep assert_allclose | grep -v atol | wc -l
258
```
good point, maybe we want to send pr to change these place preemptively

The "global scope" is a bit misleading, as it means global memory in GPU, or the memory that can actually be seen by the user. In CPU, everything is "global memory", although llvm may promote constant arrays into register. 

The special memory "local, shared" is only enabled when we tag them to be so

Yes, in this case, the allocate should be in the for loop(as shown in your code). We probably want to send an warning as well, because usually non-fixed size temporal memory means dynamic memory allocation and we can only use DRAM(CPU memory) and global scope

```
Linux raspberrypi 4.14.70-v7+ #1144 SMP Tue Sep 18 17:34:46 BST 2018 armv7l GNU/Linux
cat /etc/debian_version
9.4
```
the compilation works fine on raspberry Pi if I remove "-device=arm_cpu" from target line

I think there are some problems with 32bit environment as you mentioned before.
But we always use cross compilation because building tvm and running compilation on rasp is slow.

BTW, why do you need to run code on rasp?
I need to run autotvm for raspberry Pi. It's more reliable to run it locally on the device itself.

Running autotvm on rasp will be extremely slow!
The RPC server/tracker for linux is very stable. We didn't observe any problem for long tuning tasks.

I strongly agree with the numpy consistency, e.g. `nnvm.symbol.flatten` should be renamed.

A good example could be that TensorFlow's API uses `batch_xxx` for batched operators.

@zhiics @srkreddy1238 @MarisaKirisame please review again

This is not necessarily the problem of type functor itself. The type functor signature has nothing wrong and can workes accordingly. The problem is that if a value is passed once by rvalue reference, it only get moved twice which causes the error. When a user declares the argument of rvalue reference, they really should be aware of this problem.

I would say that TypeVisitor should never have such additional arguments. In most cases where we need the additional Args signature, we can just use TypeFunctor instead

Oh, yes, I meant to say ci_cpu. Using nightly is fine. However, note that we build the docker image infrequently, which means we will be stuck to a certain version of nightly. Using a stable version  or hashtag is preferred

One note about int32 vs int64 when constructing constant was raised by @junrushao1994 @srkreddy1238 . This is an issue we should think about now. int32 will likely cause some regression on large arrays which need to be fixed. I think we should prefer int64 when possible for constants, and let the compiler to automatically detect and downgrade to int32. 

A temporary workaround is always to keep the inferred shape type consistent with the input shape type, and we can make the switch more easily in one place later

Another thing I am concerning is user friendliness.

First, examples provided by Python API docs should be at least runnable by copy-pasting, like PyTorch (https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/tensors.html) or NumPy (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.expand_dims.html).

Second, Python API docs should be self-contained, at least those designed for DL practitioners who may not take a good look at the C++ code.

It does not seem to be a big deal for now, but we should put more effort into it in the future.

+1 for API docs friendless, I would recommend we do it now than later. Maybe I am having a bad lead example in the conv2d docs as it was pretty minimum, I will send an updated PR to update that, and let us make sure the new ops are being well documented with examples, especially non-trival ones

Expr like below is not getting simplified !!

```TensorTypeNode(float32, [n, c, int32((float32(100)*2.000000f)), int32((float32(200)*2.000000f))])```

any idea ?
The eager CSE is done among integer expression only so far. For floating points, we still need to call explicitly simplification, or use as_const_int to get out and explicit simplify
